column1:
DESCRIPTION


Inspects Velocity of a trend on M5 chart
column2: • when velocity is overbought it start a session and performs a buy
column3:
and
  • when velocity is oversold it performs a sell


    • INDICATORS

    • Velocity



    PERIOD

    • M5 Period only


    BUY

    • velocity is overbought


    SELL



    STOP LOSS



    TAKE PROFIT



    EXIT

column1:
DESCRIPTION


Checks CandleStick patterns and trigger buy or sell action;


This strategy is only to confirm patterns ; not to use.


INDICATORS


BAR


PERIOD


Any


BUY


Previous bar is a Bull Candle except for BULL_ENGULFING


SELL


Previous bar is a Bea Candle except for BEAR_ENGULFING


CLOSE BUY


Sell action


CLOSE SELL

Buy Action



STOP LOSS



TAKE PROFIT



EXIT


No trades in session

column3: 136);">In a UP Trend or DOWN Trend
column4: wait for a correction to finish and then take the trade.
column6:
136);">UP Trend : EMA 8 above EMA 20

DOWN Trend : EMA 8 below EMA 20


PERIOD

  • Any time frame (H1 is a good period)


BUY

  • Up Trend
  • High of the current bar above High of the previous bar
  • Low of the Previous bar lower than its previous (lower low)
  • High of the previous bar lower than its previous (lower high)

SELL

  • Down Trend
  • High of the current bar above High of the previous bar
  • Low of the Previous bar higher than its previous (higher low)
  • High of the previous bar higher than its previous (higher high)


STOP LOSS

  • 2 times the value of ATR


TAKE PROFIT

  • 2 times the value of ATR


EXIT

  • On closing trade take profit or stop loss

column21: 136);">The QCS system is based around 4 by D1 candle formations with respect to the following:
column23: 136);">a) 2 bullish candles followed by 2 bearish candles looking to go short the market
column27: 136);">b) 2 bearish candles followed by 2 bullish candles looking to go long the market
column31: 136);">The Basic Version of a QCS entry uses the Quad Candle Patterns and the Master Octive Trading Frame (indicator).

column59: 136);">Entry occurs after Quad Candle Pattern completes meaning after D1 candle close and up until 5 minutes prior to the Entry Candles Close.
column61: 136);">Consider any impact of spread at time of entry as applicable such as end of NY Session through into the Asian Session when spread(s) might be 'high'.
column65: 136);">A valid entry must occur within the QCS Entry Candle time.
column67: 136);">The QCS Entry Candle is the next candle in the sequence after a valid Quad Pattern is confirmed.
column69: 136);">D1 TF = Entry within Open and Close of the QCS Entry Candle (D1);
column71: 136);">W1 TF = Entry within Open and Close of the QCS Entry Candle (W1).
column73: 136);">Similarly for other time frames being traded.
column75: 136);">Since entry can be made within the relevant QCS Entry Candle

column90: 136);"> of the valid Quad Candle Pattern with an entry set at 38.2 or 50.0 or 61.8.
column96: 136);"> is if price does not pullback and instead continues in the setup direction leaving you on the sidelines resulting in a missed opportunity or having to enter at a less than favorable price.
column102: 136);"> to enter too late into a trade based on an assessment of Pips Moved versus ADR (if D1 traded).
column104: 136);">Trader discretion may well be required at times based around their own trading plan and the particular symbol being considered.
column106: 136);">A Quad Pattern is valid at any location on the chart (provided broker datafeed is current and no missing data is present) meaning it does not have to be in an Extreme Zone (potentially longer pip tallies occur from entries made near the extreme zones provided stopout does not occur).
column108: 136);">Chart Structure and Confluence should be applied in all QCS Setups to provide an entry with the highest probabilistic outcome.
column110: 136);">If it is not then a reduced applied risk should be used such as trading same SL pips but at half the volume meaning 1/2 'normal' risk.
column122: 136);"> should follow the Quad pattern entry criteria as posted above;

column131: 136);"> can follow same bias Quad Pattern but they do not need too.
column133: 136);">The addition of trades (2 or more) are at the discretion of the trader and can be based on the following:
column135: 136);">a) Master Octive Trading Frame price levels:
column146: 136);">Additional Entry D @ Entry 1 price +/- 5 OGs
column148: 136);">Note 1: Allow a minimum 2 Octive Gaps before adding in the first additional trade
column149: this is to give brathing space to Entry 1 and allow for some PnL.
column153: D etc can then be set as pending orders at 1 OG apart using Master Octive Trading Frame price levels if desired.
column155: 136);">Note 2: Additional trades should not be applied any closer than 2 OGs from the main target zone;
column157: 136);">b) Quad Patterns (next in series or in confluence with S&R levels);
column161: 136);">d) Support + Resistance and Chart Structure;
column167: 136);">g) Range Ratios (eg. Pips moved Vs ADR/AWR/AMR etc);
column171: 136);">Note 1: The addition of all trades that form a Quad Setup must be designed such that the sum total of all the SLs is less than the total assigned risk.
column173: 136);">Note 2: The assigned risk per trade is typically in the range 0.5% - 5%.
column175: 136);">Note 3: The total assigned risk across the account is typically 1.5% - 15% for a cycle of 3 to 5 trades.
column177: 136);">Note 4: It is highly recommended that minimal risk be applied on initial entries and as trading progresses favorably then increase trading volume.
column179: 136);">The 1st entry is arguably the most important of the sequence of trades in a Quad Setup since it is in a location that the trader expects to be the start of a new super trend either UP or DOWN as the case may be and the addition of trades is expected to add considerably to the growth of the account.
column181: 136);">The careful addition of trades to a given Quad Setup is what provides the potential acceleration in growth.
column183: 136);">At all times the risk should be monitored and controlled as much as possible from the traders end.
column185: 136);">Some risk such as broker negative slippage
column186: flash crashes and black swan events may not be possible to control by the trader.
column188: 136);">I may not share the 'advanced tools' though so please keep this in mind.
column192: 136);">P=64 [Period in bars] is the default settings however the Advanced Toolkit has open possibilities.
column194: 136);">Note: Default settings should be applied on a D1 TF unless otherwise stated.
column196: 136);">Splitting the Symbols into different speeds (ADR's):
column204: 136);">A specific setting can be applied to a given symbol or alternatively an average 'best fit'.
column206: 136);">The Octive Gaps shown on the Master Octive Trading Frame may change size when the parameters are altered (advanced version only).
column208: 136);">In cases where the PA is seen to be 'out-of-sync' then we need to change the settings (advanced version only) slightly.
column212: 136);">Generally placed above or below the Quad Candle Cluster (QCC) depending on a short or long setup.
column214: 136);">The Quad Candle Cluster is the grouping of candles (or bars) that form the Quad Candle Pattern and any adjacent (and close) candles.
column216: 136);">Typically this is when a few nearby candles have ranges above a Quad Short Pattern or below a Quad Long Pattern and its desirable to have a stop that clears these levels.
column218: 136);">Basically above or below the major swings as in the Quad Candle Cluster (Quad Pattern and any immediate bars forming structure).
column221: the following may be used at the discretion of the trader:
column223: 136);">1. Swing Highs or Lows or at QCC locations as mentioned above (allow a
column227: 136);"> above/below this level) including a 2 OG SL that clears this area and does not fall within the range;
column229: 136);">2. ATR trace indicator (used for possibly trailing of stops);
column231: 136);">3. Chart structural highs or lows as the case dictates;
column239: 136);">) is to be made from either the
column249: 136);">i) minimum SL of at least 50% of the current Octive Gap should be applied
column251: 136);">ii) maximum SL of 100% of the current Octive Gap
column253: 136);">b) all other SLs from Octive levels should be a minimum of 1 Octive Gap up to a maximum of 2 Octive Gaps.
column255: 136);">c) exceptions should be very very limited and relate to risk control parameters.
column261: 136);">The Stop Loss must never exceed 1 Octive Gap (refer Master Octive Trading Frame)
column265: 136);"> the OPL_Top level for a Quad Short Setup.
column267: 136);">The Stop Loss must also NOT exceed 2 Octive Gaps.
column271: 136);">The Stop Loss must never exceed 1 Octive Gap (refer Master Octive Trading Frame)
column275: 136);"> the OPL_Base level for a Quad Long Setup.
column277: 136);">The Stop Loss must also NOT exceed 2 Octive Gaps.
column279: 136);">6. Initial SL settings should remain in place until price has moved a minimum 2 Octive Gaps in the favored direction then 1 OG can be locked in;
column281: 136);">7. SL can be applied after 2 consecutive opposite candles have closed (QSS: close after 2 bullish candles; QLS: close after 2 bearish candles) under floating profit conditions else allow the trade to run on accepting stopout in a worse case scenario.
column285: 136);">The targets are set after applying the stop loss settings in a minimum 1 RR (better 2:1
column287: 4:1 or higher) which are based on the Octive Gap.
column289: 136);">Minimum Take Profit is 1 Octive Gap (1RR).
column291: 136);">If 1 Octive Gap is the chosen SL then its possible to set up to a max 10RR target (Short OPL_Top down to OPL_0 or Long OPL_Base up to OPL_8).
column293: 136);">If higher Octive Gap ratios are selected for the SL then the maximum RR levels will reduce since the SL pips have clearly increased and yet the MOTF remains unchanged in terms of available target pips (ie the MOTF when set has a fixed range).
column295: 136);">We do not set targets into the Upper or Lower Extreme Zones since it is within these zones that we seek a reversal PA to unfold.
column297: 136);">Maximum target level for a Quad Short Setup is the OPL_8 level.
column299: 136);">Maximum target level for a Quad Long Setup is the OPL_0 level.
column301: 136);">Minimum target level for either setup is 1 Octive Gap.
column305: 136);">Trades may be trailed as the trader sees fit either manually or automated process.
column307: 136);">I recommend on the initial entry to allow a minimum of 2 Octive Gaps before trailing at 1 Octive Gap.
column309: 136);">This comes based on experience which shows that PA can whipsaw 1 Octive Gap taking you out so trail from greater than 1 Octive such as 2 OGs until the trade has progressed over several OG levels and is seen to being met with strong Support or Resistance (based on chart structure).
column311: 136);">Alternatively a trader can use:
column313: 136);">a) BE + some pips after price has moved favorably X_pips where X_pips > 1 OG;
column318: 136);">c) Master Octive Trading Frame indicator;
column320: 136);">d) Chart structure (eg longer term Support or Resistance zones or Candlestick Trailing);
column322: 136);">e) 2 by D1 opposite colored candles (in series) form anytime after trade entry (floating profit showing); or
column328: 136);">Note that the trailing method applied is determined by the trader.
column330: 136);">It is logical to give lower relative volume entries larger breathing space as opposed to the higher relative volume entries later in the cycle.
column332: 136);">Price will not always go in the direction you would like and indeed it may reverse after going a certain number of pips so it is sometimes necessary to simply close out the trade for some profit or a loss and search for the next opportunity.
column334: 136);">Often the trader will need to balance between applying too tight of a stop and too generous of a stop.
column336: 136);">I recommend considering the symbols ADR/AWR/AMR data in combination with the current Octive Gap when trailing.
column338: 136);">Too tight of a stop and you might be kicked out of the trade too soon.
column340: 136);">Too generous of a stop and you might give back too much floating profit.

column1:
DESCRIPTION


Wait for a correction to finish on a topped bar or bottomed bar



INDICATORS


BAR

HIGH

LOW

ATR



PERIOD


Above M30
column2:
H4 is a good period


BUY


Actual bar is bull with higher high preceded by a minimum of 2 bear bars


SELL


Actual bar is bear with a lower low preceded by minimum 2 bull bars


STOP LOSS


Based on ATR


TAKE PROFIT


Based on ATR


EXIT


No more trades we exit session

column5:
0);">Ace284

FOREX FACTORY https://www.forexfactory.com/thread/168161-4h-box-breakout




I've seen breakout strategies for daily and weekly. I've never seen one like the one i'm about to present.


DRAW a box connecting the high of the first 4hr candle(00:00) of the week with the low along with a buffer of 20 pips on each side.

The week starts at the open of the Australian session.

If I had a penny for every time someone has asked which candle it is..i wouldn't need to trade forex to make money. For the next person who is going to ask
column6:
follow these instructions.

Download an FXDD platform. Press Ctrl y on a 4hr chart. Lines will magically pop up and at the start of every week the first 4hr candle should form on the line. This is the candle you use for the High and Low.


Box Forming Times:

GMT- 21:00 to 01:00

EDT - 17:00 to 21:00

FXDD time - 00:00 to 04:00


Use Time zone conversion to find out your specific time.


DO NOT ask when the bar forms and when it closes as its been answered MULTIPLE times. I post every week when the bar closes. If you're not willing to go through the thread or wait one week for my post on when the bar closes than this system isn't for you.

I'm sorry
column7:
but it's just gotten to a point where people ask every time.


Some brokers begin operating an hour earlier then FXDD or later. If you first 4Hr bar closes at 00:00 GMT
column8:
then that's not the right candle. The best thing to do is to download an FXDD demo platform and use that as reference.

Rules:

- Add a buffer of 10-20 pips on each end of candle

- Buy on upper break of weekly box (including buffer spread)

- Sell on lower break of weekly box (including buffer)


SL - other side of Box

TP1 - 1x box size

TP2 - 2x box size

TP3 - 3x box size

TP4 - 4x box size


This system works on many JPY pairs.

GBP/JPY

EUR/JPY

AUD/JPY

CHF/JPY

CAD/JPY

**GBP/JPY is the best pair.

May work on other pairs
column9:
testing is required however.



I like to use 3x-4x box size as TP.

I take don't profits at 1x size of box because larger reward is key.


I move stop to BE after 1x has been hit.


Risk Management (to find out your position size)


(Account Balance * Risk percent)/Stoploss = mini lot size


Advantages

- 30 mins a week

- no worrying about charts filled with indicators

- higher reward than risk on EACH trade

- easy to back test


Important:

- no worrying about charts filled with indicators

- higher reward than risk on EACH trade

- easy to back test

column30: 2009 9:27pm

column3: always looking for tops and bottoms trying get in as early as possible
column4: but we know that is not as easy as it seems and many times we land up with fake reversals or temporary pullbacks
column5:
chasing and adding to losing positions etc etc..


Now I'm sure most of us have heard the sayings that the "trend is your friend"
column6: "follow the trend" and "trade with the trend" etc so I gave this some serious thought and came up with an idea that I have been working on for many months now. I know that there are probably 1000's of trend based strategies and perhaps mine is not unique
column7:
but it has been showing positive results with minimal time and effort. I wanted to create a strategy that is easy to follow and with as less chart and screen time needed (max 10 mins) kind of like a set and forget approach.


So here goes! The first thing you need is the Trend indicator LuXingMod AUD indicator
column8: this is a free indicator I found here on FF
column9: it simply shows all the pairs candle direction for each time frame if it is green/up or red/down
column10:
simple. I've attached it to this thread.


Now what is the entry criteria and when do we open and close an order?


1. First we will edit the indicator settings to only show the H4
column13:
MN bars/candles as we are only looking at higher time frame trends.

2. When? On a Monday night 1 hour before the first daily candle of the week closes we will look for any pairs where is a confluence between the trend on all 4 time frames.

3. Any pairs that have the same confluence on all 4 time frames we will open an order in the same direction.

4. I normally wait for the first daily candle to be pretty much fully formed so more or less 1 hour before the Monday daily close.

5. When do we take profit? You take profit when you are happy with it or you can set your own TP in pips or %. I have set a 5% TP.

6. What about a stop loss? Well this is a personal preference
column14:
but I'm setting a max of 10% so if my account goes -10% of my account equity I'll close up for the week.

7. Can we set a trailing stop to trail profits? Sure that would be a good idea after reaching your TP.

8. This whole process should take you max 10 mins to look for valid pairs and place your orders.

9. Anything else? No that's it
column15:
simple right?


This is a really easy strategy guys
column17:
we are simply following the overall main trend of the market. This is a weekly basket style approach where we will hold orders for 2-4 days depending on the market. This strategy does not take into account fundamentals or high impact news events so if you want to be extra cautious you can exclude any valid pairs that might be affected by related news events for the week.


If you guys have some ideas on how to improve on the strategy I'm open to listening
column18:
however I will not encourage ideas that will completely deviate from the original strategy as its really simple and I don't want to complicate things.


I'm a fan of EA's and think they are great tools if used correctly so I had an EA made for me based on this strategy. The EA is pretty straight forward I think and should be easy enough to understand. The EA is also pretty customizable so you can also trade it on other sessions and time frames
column19:
you only need to configure the settings accordingly.


I have also decided to extend the expiry date and have set the expiry to 31/12/2020 so the EA will work until the end of the year. This EA to protect it from being sold or commercialized etc.


*Due to some members comments I felt the need to state publicly that the Follow the Candles EA is FREE and always will be! The is no hidden commercial agenda or plans to sell the EA at any time.!*


Please guys lets stay on topic and try not to deviate too much from the original strategy. I will not tolerate any arguing or keyboard warriors
column20:
those that can't participate in a respectful friendly manner will be removed.


Green pips to you all! Cheers! :-)
